awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Moira Gresham at Whitman College. 

Astrophysical measurements indicate that most of the matter in the Universe is composed of an unknown form of matter that we call "dark matter".  Observational evidence indicates that our current understanding of elementary particles cannot account for it;  most dark matter is not composed of protons, neutrons, and electrons like the "normal matter" whose building blocks we understand well.  Uncovering the nature of dark matter will help us to better understand the contents of the cosmos and how our galaxy and solar system came to be.  An understanding of the identity of dark matter may also help to revolutionize our model of the building blocks of all matter.  Research into the nature of dark matter will thus advance the national interest by promoting the progress of fundamental physical science.  The road to understanding the nature of dark matter will involve the synthesis of observations from a wide variety of particle and astrophysics experiments.  In order to derive meaning from observations --- especially when they come in diverse forms --- it is critical to understand the theoretical possibilities for dark matter and their associated phenomenologies.  In her research, Professor Gresham will investigate a compelling class of possibilities for dark matter that are also related to the currently unexplained fact that the vast majority of normal matter is in the form of particles rather than an equal share of both particles and anti-particles.  Professor Gresham's research activities will also have significant broader impacts.  They will enhance undergraduate education through direct involvement of undergraduates in her research and will increase her ability to make exciting contemporary particle astrophysics and cosmology topics accessible to undergraduates.  Professor Gresham will also help to increase the participation of women in physics through her mentoring of undergraduate women and girls in the community.  Finally, she will help to increase science literacy in her rural community by engaging in science outreach to the public schools.

More technically, Professor Gresham will investigate the astrophysics and cosmology of dark-matter sectors with a matter/anti-matter asymmetry mirroring the matter/anti-matter asymmetry in the visible matter sector.  A distinctive possibility within such asymmetric dark matter (ADM) models is the clumping or collection of dark matter in other astrophysical objects;  by contrast, symmetric dark matter tends to annihilate (particle with anti-particle) in such circumstances.  Professor Gresham will begin by investigating a class of ADM models in which the formation of bound states of ADM may have rich implications for the formation of structures (e.g., galaxies and stars) in the universe.  Comparison of theoretical models to a diverse set of observations, including possibly observations of gravitational waves, will be necessary.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF WHITMAN COLLEGE

por.por_cntn:
Dark matter bound states analogous to electrically neutral nuclei can be naturally realized within the context of asymmetric dark matter. Conversely, such states would not exist in our universe if the dark matter were symmetric---that is, composed of roughly equal parts matter and anti-matter. Therefore, large bound states of dark matter could be a smoking gun signature of asymmetric dark matter. But how large could these bound states grow in our universe? And what astrophysics observations could signal their existence?

 

This project provided partial answers to these questions, helping to advance our understanding of the possible particle physics nature of dark matter, while also highlighting new ways that dark matter physics could affect presently unexplained or emerging astrophysics observations. For example, within a generic dark matter model including a single variety of dark matter particle obeying the Pauli exclusion principle along with attractive and repulsive dark forces, we found that dark matter bound states could be synthesized up to masses of order 100 micrograms in the early universe while still being consistent with observations limiting dark forces. When these large bound states interact in the late universe, they generically fuse exothermically---implying dark matter density profiles towards the centers of galaxies that could differ substantially from profiles given non-interacting dark matter or dark matter that interacts primarily via scattering.

 

Exothermic dark matter fusion also provides a mechanism for larger dark matter bound states to form, and motivates consideration of the gravitational stability of very large compact objects composed of dark matter. This project also delineated the structure and limits on the sizes of very large, gravitationally stable compact objects composed of dark matter within the generic model described above. The existence of such objects could manifest in gravitational wave searches, for example. Above a certain size, these objects would collapse into black holes, and this project set the stage for considering a possible dark matter mechanism to explain the existence and distribution of supermassive black holes in our universe. Furthermore, this project delineated the amount of collected dark matter that can destabilize a neutron star, and corrected the existing literature on this point. 

 

This project also included two subproject extensions that grow from but reach beyond the asymmetric dark matter model investigated above. One subproject delineated limits on a macroscopic-range (kilometers and beyond) fifth force between dark matter and normal matter from observations of neutron star temperatures and pulsar timing arrays. The second is a pedagogical publication aimed at an advanced undergraduate audience, written with two undergraduate coauthors. It explored a quantum mechanical model closely related to hydrogen and deuterium that can also describe two-body bound states of dark matter. 

 

This award also directly supported summer research experiences for three Whitman College students who subsequently matriculated in physics and astronomy PhD programs. The PI also mentored six other summer and thesis research undergraduate students conducting research related to this project. Five of the nine mentored research students were women, students of color, and/or first-generation working-class students. As part of this project, the PI participated in science outreach in her local rural community, including giving a public lecture on dark matter and hosting a Q&A session for Whitman staff, faculty, family, and students on Dark Matter Day.  In support of diversity, equity, and inclusion within physics and society, the PI participated as a National Mentoring Community mentor, advised the Women in STEM club at Whitman, and brought the National Academy of Sciences' Creative Mind traveling exhibit on contributions of African Americans to science to Whitman. 

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2022
Modified by: Moira Gresham
